description: {"blocks":[{"key":"a9c1p","text":"I inherited this protocol while working as a postdoctoral researcher in the laboratory of Dr. Stewart Scherer in the 1990s. Literature that influenced protocol development is listed in the References section. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"crmho","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmosi","text":"This protocol describes how to isolate chromosome-sized DNA from yeast cells. The yeast cells are encased in agarose, then the cell is digested away. The result is unsheared chromosomes in an agarose plug that can be loaded onto electrophoresis gels or subjected to additional analysis such as digestion with restriction enzymes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bljdr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1hacd","text":"The protocol details two sets of electrophoresis conditions for separating the chromosomes using a BioRad CHEF-DR III variable angle electrophoresis system. Because the protocol was developed for work with Candida albicans, the conditions are most useful for chromosomes in the size range of approximately 0.5 to 5 Mb. The \"short protocol\" (Condition 1) separates the smaller C. albicans chromosomes (approximately 1 Mb) without running them off the bottom of the gel. The \"long protocol\" (Condition 2) separates the larger chromosomes (approximately 3 Mb) with approximately 0.1 Mb resolution but risks running smaller DNA molecules off the gel. We typically run samples using both electrophoresis protocols and combine the resulting information to understand the karyotype.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":206,"length":16},{"style":"italic","offset":376,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
image_attribution: A portion of a CHEF gel run using this protocol. Lane 1 = Candida albicans chromosomes; Lane 2 = Lodderomyces elongisporus chromosomes; Lane 3 = Yamadazyma tenuis chromosomes

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5or4r","text":"Grow the yeast strain on an agar plate, streaking for isolated colonies. Plates can be stored at   until needed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":97,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6kd75","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6l7hm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5nc8l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ffv0r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fv3mb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ms81","text":"Select a well-isolated, representative colony. Inoculate it into the liquid growth medium of your choice. Cultures can be incubated to saturation or harvested at an earlier time point, as long as a sufficient number of cells are available (see below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"egnuc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9rs1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"27d0s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16tn7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9mj3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"297bs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"5001FF30B3A411EDB56199451710A939","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":63},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":161}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6hnih","text":"My laboratory keeps its yeast stocks frozen in 38% glycerol at  . A fresh agar plate is made from the frozen stock for each experiment. Stock plates are kept at   for no longer than 1 week. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"ED396D4AC27D11EDA31C0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"},"1":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"ED396DAFC27D11EDA31C0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":144}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2hgf","text":"My laboratory typically uses YPD medium (per liter: 10 g Bacto yeast extract, 20 g Bacto peptone, 20 g dextrose). A 50-ml Erlenmeyer flask with   of liquid medium provides more than enough cells for this protocol.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"20","error":false,"guid":"F71B7B08C27D11EDA31C0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"}}}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"do1dt","text":"This protocol works well for freshly grown yeast cells, as well as for flasks of cells that sat on the lab bench for several days.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"642af","text":"Count the yeast cells using a hemacytometer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v5qi","text":"For \"1x\" plugs, use 2 x 108 cells total for a single recipe; for \"2x\" plugs, use 4 x 108 cells total.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":26,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":87,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arnpc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1hh93","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e7ukg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dnrp2","text":"\"1x\" plugs are sufficient for visualizing chromosomes to understand the species karyotype and for Southern blotting of the agarose gel. The photo that is on the title page of this protocol used \"1x\" plugs.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3sg33","text":"\"2x\" plugs are more useful for procedures like random breakage mapping or restriction enzyme digestion of chromosomal DNA.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6n151","text":"Resuspend cells in     EDTA,  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":19,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":21,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":29,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f03ts","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cibv1","text":"Since the presence of the yeast cells increases the overall volume in the microfuge tube, measure the true volume using a Pipetteman. Set the Pipetteman for a larger volume than expected, pull up the entire volume into the pipette tip and carefully dial the Pipetteman back until the liquid is just at the end of the pipette tip. Read the Pipetteman volume and make a note of it for Step 7 (below). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"en6am","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"o0i6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ehn69","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"200","error":false,"guid":"E28C00B0AD4811EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"EF4D6230AD4811EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28}},"2":{"type":"ph","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0A5C6A80AD4911EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"number":"8.0"}},"3":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uk5l","text":"Be careful not to shoot the cell suspension out of the end of the pipette tip, especially if working with pathogens.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

The bottle of LMP agarose/EDTA can be stored at room temperature and remelted when another set of chromosome plugs is made.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"11":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"p8ll","text":"The recipe above is for 1.5% LMP agarose, which results in a final plug of 0.75% agarose (see below). Alternatively, plugs can be made using a 1% Low-Melting-Point agarose stock (0.5% agarose final concentration), but the 0.5% agarose plugs are fragile and more-difficult to handle.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"12":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2370n","text":"Some protocols may mention use of EDTA, pH 7.5. This reagent is difficult to make because of the pH-dependent solubility of EDTA. EDTA, pH 8.0 works fine for this protocol.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"10","error":false,"guid":"AA0334E0C28111ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"3":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"0.5","error_concentration":false,"guid":"BBE4FEF0C28111ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":22}},"4":{"type":"ph","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E5D6C220C28111ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"number":"8.0"}},"5":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"30","error":false,"guid":"EE8385C0C28111ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"6":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"0.6","error":false,"guid":"FA618C20C28111ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6}},"7":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"40","error":false,"guid":"2E4C4200C28211ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"8":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"5EBCEC50C28211ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"37","unit":10}},"9":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":142}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1eqa9","text":"Low-melting-point (LMP) agarose is not the regular agarose that typically is used to run electrophoresis gels. LMP agarose can be remelted at   , which is below the melting temperature for double-stranded DNA. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A9DF4410C27F11ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"65","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7g257","text":"Note the volume for each sample you are preparing. Total volume = (EDTA + cell volume measured in Step 5) +   Zymolyase-containing solution from Step 6.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":108,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5ai04","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"55ucu","text":"Make a 1:1 mix of the cell preparation with the LMP agarose. In other words, add an equal amount of LMP agarose (from Step 2) to the tube containing the cells. Mix well and immediately distribute into plug molds.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9oqme","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5uh23","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b49m3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"glft","text":"Allow filled molds to cool at   for at least  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":30,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":45,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"15","error":false,"guid":"C13C9230C28311ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":25,"offset":97,"style":"italic"},{"length":16,"offset":170,"style":"italic"},{"length":11,"offset":363,"style":"italic"}],"key":"adcbg","text":"Two kinds of plug molds are available from Bio-Rad. Thicker plugs (which give good resolution of Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosomes but are too thick to resolve larger Candida albicans chromosomes sharply) can be made using catalog number 170-3713 plug molds. Thinner plugs can be made with a reusable mold (catalog number 170-3622) and are ideal for resolving C. albicans chromosomes. The image at the start of this protocol was from plugs made with the thinner mold.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"3E3BC01CC28511ED88320A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"3":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":1800,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"3E3BC08EC28511ED88320A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"scientificNotation":false,"start":null,"temperature":"4","unit":10}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"anbr0","text":"Remove the solidified agarose plugs from the molds.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"99iia","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9oup","text":"When using the thinner mold, final plugs are larger than the electrophoresis gel well. The plugs can be cut into equal thirds using a razor blade. Working on a chilled glass plate keeps the plugs solid during the process of cutting them.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2oi90","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cep6j","text":"Plugs will be incubated overnight at   for the Zymolyase digestion to occur. Plugs can be placed into tubes, or into the wells of a 6-well tissue culture plate. It is easier to handle the plugs if they are placed into the wells of a 6-well tissue culture plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":37,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":42,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6t1b3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1aprr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d3d7l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cs1u","text":"Plugs will be incubated in a Tris/EDTA solution that is made by mixing: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7i39n","text":"0.2 ml 1 M Tris-HCl, pH 8.0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4f1mb","text":"20 ml 0.5 M EDTA, pH 8.0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk8r1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fqe6","text":"Add several ml of the solution to each well in the tissue culture plate. Distribute the plugs into the wells as needed for your experiment. Use a flat spatula (e.g. like those used for weighing chemicals) to lift each plug and release it into the tissue-culture-plate well. Make sure the plugs are covered with the buffer and add a little extra to accommodate moderate evaporation during incubation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehbkf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekvrc","text":"Incubate at   overnight without agitation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":12,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"6B66EFEEC36911EDACD10A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"30","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"77bj8","text":"Each tissue culture well can contain the entire set of plugs from a given species/strain. The recipe described above fills three of the thinner plug mold wells. When cut into thirds, the recipe yields 9 plugs for each species/strain. The recipe can be scaled up if more plugs are needed.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"7EFA74B0C28711ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"30","unit":10}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"93vd3","text":"Remove the tissue-culture plate from the incubator and pipette off the incubation buffer. Wash the plugs three times in   EDTA   (15-30 min per wash). Agitate the plate gently during washing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":120,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":127,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"du9t8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe473","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4mq0a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"0.5","error_concentration":false,"guid":"4354A7C0AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":21}},"1":{"type":"ph","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"47830F30AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"number":"9.5"}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1ulpu","text":"Make sure to handle plugs gently to avoid breaking them during this procedure.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4nurg","text":"The plugs will next be subjected to Proteinase K digestion, which is more efficient at a higher temperature. The plugs should be placed into a round-bottom tube with a cap that can limit evaporation. We use 14-ml round-bottom tubes like Nunc catalog number 150268, but many other choices would work well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"alc9l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cf8ja","text":"Proteinase K Digestion Solution Recipe:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cm2nr","text":"Since Proteinase K is expensive, prepare only the amount of this solution that is needed for the number of plugs being prepared.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e7nmu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3cqe","text":"      Final solution  Stock  Vol. needed for 5 ml     2.5 mg/mI Proteinase K  Powder  12.5 mg    1% Sarcosyl  10%  0.5 ml    0.5 M EDTA pH 9.5  0.5 M  5 ml    10 mM Tris-HCI, pH 9.5  1 M  50 µl  ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":195}],"data":{}},{"key":"9mm3n","text":"Mix the proteinase K digestion solution well and distribute a small amount into each tube. Carefully place the plugs into the tube. All plugs from the same species/strain can be placed in a single tube. Add more digestion solution to ensure that the plugs are covered completely. Place the cap on the tube tightly.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sdsk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rhsf","text":"Incubate   at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":9,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":14,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ksjq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","0_2":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","2_2":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","3_2":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","4_2":""},"colTitles":["","",""],"colWidths":["174","66","152"],"data":[["\u003cb\u003eFinal solution","\u003cb\u003eStock","\u003cb\u003eVol. needed for 5 ml\u0026nbsp;"],["~ 2.5 mg/mI Proteinase K","Powder","12.5 mg"],["~ 1% Sarkosyl","10%","0.5 ml"],["~ 0.5 M EDTA pH 9.5","0.5 M","5 ml"],["~ 10 mM Tris-HCI, pH 9.5","1 M","50 µl"]],"guid":"42D98897AD4811EDAED40A58A9FEAC02","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":"","mergeCells":{},"printData":[["\u003cb\u003eFinal solution","\u003cb\u003eStock","\u003cb\u003eVol. needed for 5 ml\u0026nbsp;"],["~ 2.5 mg/mI Proteinase K","Powder","12.5 mg"],["~ 1% Sarkosyl","10%","0.5 ml"],["~ 0.5 M EDTA pH 9.5","0.5 M","5 ml"],["~ 10 mM Tris-HCI, pH 9.5","1 M","50 µl"]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23]}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":1800,"guid":"4CBE3454C28911ED88320A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":["overnight"],"start":null}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":1800,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"4CBE356FC28911ED88320A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":["overnight"],"scientificNotation":false,"start":null,"temperature":"50","unit":10}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3qpk1","text":"Carefully pour the plugs from the tube into a well on a 6-well tissue culture plate. Wash plugs three times with   EDTA   working similarly to Step 9.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":113,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":120,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ava77","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"ADC298B0AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28}},"1":{"type":"ph","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B4E86E30AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"number":"8.0"}}}}

steps.section: How to Make Agarose-Embedded Yeast Chromsomes (Chromosome Plugs)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"rti3","text":"Store plugs at   in   EDTA  . Plugs may be stored in the tissue culture plate, but evaporation of buffer occurs over time. Place them in a capped tube or check the plates at routine intervals to ensure that the plugs do not dry out.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":15,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":20,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":27,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"909k2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"n76l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fo4n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"C3A837C0AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"C7828BC0AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":28}},"2":{"type":"ph","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D05FD540AD4A11EDA52C23A06D656E2A","id":0,"number":"8.0"}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"36p06","text":"We have stored plugs successfully for years without loss of quality.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Separating Yeast Chromosomes on a Pulsed-Field Electrophoresis Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"60evv","text":"Prepare the buffer and agarose gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"90a5t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"db0hv","text":"Separation of chromosome-sized DNA is best accomplished using Pulsed Field Certified Agarose (e.g. Bio-Rad catalog number 162-0137). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":62,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq263","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7ovj","text":"Both sets of gel running conditions described below use 1x Tris-Acetate-EDTA (TAE) buffer. TAE buffer is made at a 50x concentration and diluted to 1x just before use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bvg8n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ah5gi","text":"50x TAE Recipe","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c47ub","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eqt5u","text":"Prepare the gel by dissolving the correct amount of Pulsed Field Certified Agarose in 1x TAE buffer. For example, the protocol called Condition 1 uses a 0.8% agarose gel. Preparing 150 ml of agarose will fill the Bio-Rad gel tray with a little extra left over. The leftover agarose is used to seal the gel wells after the plugs are loaded.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ajvf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"177mi","text":"To prepare 150 ml of 0.8% agarose in 1x TAE buffer, weigh 1.2 g Pulsed Field Certified Agarose and dissolve it in 150 ml 1x TAE buffer. Heat in a microwave or on a heating plate. A stir bar may be used on the heating plate. Cool the agarose to less than   before pouring the gel to avoid warping the gel tray.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":254,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a87b5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kh0l","text":"Pulsed field gels work best when poured on a level surface. Place the gel tray onto a leveling platform and use a bubble level to adjust. Pour the cooled agarose into the gel tray and place the comb so the teeth are closest to the frame of the gel tray. Placing the comb in the opposite orientation shortens the running length of the gel. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"83gjm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86mfj","text":"Allow the gel to solidify at room temperature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{"A_1":{"className":" "},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["","",""],"colWidths":[100,100,100],"data":[["\u003cb\u003eFinal solution","\u003cb\u003eStock","\u003cb\u003eAmount needed (per liter)"],["2 M Tris","Tris base","242 g"],["1 M Acetic Acid","Glacial acetic acid","57.1 ml"],["0.05 M EDTA, pH 8.0","0.5 M EDTA, pH 8.0","100 ml"],["","Purified water","to 1 L total volume"]],"guid":"91AD0A00C28C11ED97CB31E79275F93F","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":"","mergeCells":{},"printData":[["\u003cb\u003eFinal solution","\u003cb\u003eStock","\u003cb\u003eAmount needed (per liter)"],["2 M Tris","Tris base","242 g"],["1 M Acetic Acid","Glacial acetic acid","57.1 ml"],["0.05 M EDTA, pH 8.0","0.5 M EDTA, pH 8.0","100 ml"],["","Purified water","to 1 L total volume"]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23]}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"B3CAD600C28F11ED97CB31E79275F93F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"60","unit":10}}}}

steps.section: Separating Yeast Chromosomes on a Pulsed-Field Electrophoresis Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4vap3","text":"The CHEF system in my laboratory includes the variable-speed pump for buffer recirculation and the cooling module. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fapq6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c583","text":"Two sets of running conditions are presented below. These conditions are for use on a BioRad DR-III device. Modifications will be needed for other instruments. Both sets of conditions use 1x TAE buffer. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cohpo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0g8s","text":"The running conditions were developed for use with C. albicans chromosomes. The diploid C. albicans has eight chromosome pairs that range in size from chromosome 1 (3.2 Mb) to chromosome 7 (0.95 Mb). Chromosome R (that encodes variable rDNA copy numbers) is large, migrating in the size range of chromosome 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":51,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":88,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"euq98","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rns6","text":"Condition 1 will resolve all but chromosomes 1 and R, leaving room on the gel for chromosome fragments smaller than chromosome 7.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1puf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2uru","text":"Condition 2 will separate chromosomes 1 and R but runs chromosome 7 to near the bottom of the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Separating Yeast Chromosomes on a Pulsed-Field Electrophoresis Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c0v6i","text":"Load your plugs into the gel wells. This step takes a little practice. You will likely break some plugs before you can load them into the gel cleanly and without bubbles. It helps to add   of 1x TAE (running buffer) to the gel well, which fills it approximately half-way. Plugs tend to slide into the well more easily with the buffer present. Filling the well completely with 1x TAE tends to repel the plug from entering the well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":187,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8ag3d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4oha","text":"Once plugs are loaded, use the flat spatula to ensure that the plug is \"flush\" with the leading edge of the gel well. In other words, manipulate the plug so that its face meets the leading edge of the gel well without air bubbles or gaps. This step also takes practice. You can also use a Hamilton syringe to remove air bubbles from the well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75p4h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4cr5","text":"Once the plugs are positioned correctly, use the remaining Pulsed Field Certified Agarose/1x TAE solution to seal the plugs into the wells. This step prevents the plugs from floating away during the electrophoresis step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"100","error":false,"guid":"5484EA60C36A11ED900D6DA2053196D6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

steps.section: Separating Yeast Chromosomes on a Pulsed-Field Electrophoresis Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7k9a6","text":"Place your gel into the gel box. Allow the gel to equilibrate to the temperature of the buffer before starting the electrophoresis protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"kr1o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jtgs","text":"Set up the CHEF power supply using parameters for either Condition 1 or Condition 2:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lsua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agsdi","text":"Condition 1: 0.8% agarose gel run at   at 3 V/cm with a 106-degree angle. Running time is   with a 120-480 sec linear ramp.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":37,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":90,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"76e4e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5knm4","text":"Condition 2: 0.6% agarose gel run at   at 2.5 V/cm with a 120-degree angle. Running time is   with a 120-300 sec linear ramp followed by   with a 420-900 sec linear ramp.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":37,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":92,"length":1},{"key":4,"offset":137,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7br48","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bgksr","text":"Examine the depth of the buffer in the gel box. Ideally, the buffer should just cover the top surface of the gel. Drain excess buffer from the box.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gopl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkgmh","text":"Start the power supply and ensure that the gel is running. If you drained too much buffer in the previous step, for example, there may not be bubbles coming from the electrodes in the box. Note the milliamps at the start of the run. We typically see values of 150 mA at the start of a run; the value increases as the run progresses. If the reading is too high, try draining more buffer from the gel box. Bio-Rad literature discusses this point in detail, suggesting that the mA reading is also affected by water quality or buffer preparation problems.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"alg84","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5sfuh","text":"Monitor the run as it progresses. Ensure that there are no leaks, that the buffer level in the gel box is still acceptable, and that the chiller unit is maintaining the desired temperature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ed8s4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o0h7","text":"When the run is completed, drain the buffer from the gel box and rinse the box/tubing with water in preparation for storage or future use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A2E1A870C36E11ED900D6DA2053196D6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"14","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":180000,"guid":"5E1F208AC36B11EDACD10A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"AA0B0060C36E11ED900D6DA2053196D6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"12","unit":10}},"3":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":86400,"guid":"5E1F210DC36B11EDACD10A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"4":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":165600,"guid":"5E1F218CC36B11EDACD10A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

steps.section: Separating Yeast Chromosomes on a Pulsed-Field Electrophoresis Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6k6sg","text":"Add 1x TAE to the gel box. Start the recirculation pump and the cooling module. Select either   (Condition 1) or   (Condition 2) depending on the protocol you would like to run. It takes a little time for the buffer to reach the selected temperature so set up the gel box before loading the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":94,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":113,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"C7C64450C36B11ED900D6DA2053196D6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"14","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"CFCA1DC0C36B11ED900D6DA2053196D6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"12","unit":10}}}}
